content.webTitle: Sarah Gigante: ‘I went to sleep in my national championship jersey’ | Kieran Pender

fields.headline: Sarah Gigante: ‘I went to sleep in my national championship jersey’
fields.bodyText: The roads of Mount Buninyong, home to Australia’s annual cycling national championships, have witnessed heroics before. Some of the country’s best cyclists past and present – Amanda Spratt, Simon Gerrans, Robbie McEwen – have been crowned champion after triumphing on these treacherous Ballarat hills. But Buninyong has never before seen someone quite like Sarah Gigante. Just 18, the Victorian had already impressed by winning the road race, time trial and criterium trifecta at last year’s Under-19 national championships. Those feats, though, pale in comparison to her achievement of last Sunday. Riding against Australia’s best female riders, including world No 2 Spratt, Gigante attacked on the penultimate lap. Barely days into her first season out of the junior ranks, the recent high school graduate held off a determined chase to win both the elite and Under-23 categories – an Australian first. “I can’t believe it – this is a dream come true,” Gigante tells Guardian Australia. Having joined an early breakaway on the first lap, the youngster stayed with the front group as its numbers dwindled. When a small gap emerged between her, Sarah Roy and Shara Gillow, Gigante seized the opportunity. “When the gap opened it was a complete surprise. I thought: ‘it is now or never – I may as well try.’ It really paid off.” The magnitude of Gigante’s upset is unprecedented. She was racing against the might of World Tour team Mitchelton-Scott, the second-best female team in the world, in one of the longest races she had ever contested. Victory should not have been possible. “The win did not sink in at all on Sunday – it was just a complete dream,” says Gigante. “I went to sleep in my national championship jersey – when I woke up the next morning it felt a bit more real.” Gigante’s Buninyong glory caps a remarkable reversal of fortune. Last May the Victorian broke her elbow, shoulder and wrist following a club race crash. When Gigante told doctors she needed to be back racing by August, to contest the junior track world championships, they laughed. Yet with a concerted rehabilitation effort, Gigante found herself at the world championships – claiming silver in the points race. She backed up a month later to represent Australia in the junior category of the road world championships in Austria, before flying home to sit her final exams. Although unable to write for several months during the school year due to her injuries – she instead relied on her mother to transcribe homework – Gigante received a perfect Atar score of 99.95. Despite her pride at the result – securing a place studying science at the University of Melbourne – Gigante says the green and gold stripes are an even bigger achievement. “This is more exciting than my Atar,” she laughs. Gigante is also quick to acknowledge the role of her family in her recent successes. “My family are proud of me no matter what,” she says. “This victory is icing on the cake – but they love me for the passion I have and the hard work I put in.” 2019 will see Gigante commence her university studies and race domestically and internationally with Roxsolt-Attaquer. She may have a busy year ahead, but after enduring a trying 2018 Gigante is not phased. “Last year was really tough with year 12, the injuries and lengthy recovery period. As long as something like that does not happen again it won’t be too bad.” With her dual academic and sporting ambitions, it remains unclear where Gigante’s future will lead. “I want to take cycling as far as I can,” she says. “I love the sport and have ever since I started when I was eight. Hopefully I can keep doing that for a long time coming, keeping improving and keep going overseas. But it is good to have balance – studying gives me something to fall back on. Cycling can change so quickly.” She may be wearing national colours in 2019 – something she admits is “quite the honour” – but Gigante is not getting ahead of herself. Asked about the 2020 Olympics, she modestly demurs. “I wouldn’t say Tokyo is on my mind,” she says. “That is a long way in the future – two years away. Anything can happen. I will just focus on the now.” Barely an adult, Gigante is already a national champion, has represented Australia internationally in two cycling disciplines and aced her year 12 exams. Is there anything this friendly young rider, mature beyond her years, does not excel at? “Cleaning my room,” she quips.
